author: Shawn Langlois
title: More people are living on $1.90 a day, and, in a way, that’s a good thing
text:
By the end of the year, less than 10% of the global population, or about 702 million people, are expected to be living in extreme poverty, according to World Bank projections released over the weekend. That’s down substantially from 12.8%, or 902 million, in 2012.
The number stood at 37.1% in 1990.
“We are the first generation in human history that can end extreme poverty,” World Bank President Jim Yong Kim said, pointing to increased investments in education and health as driving factors.
By region, a reduction in poverty from 7.2% to 4.1% throughout parts of Asia provided a big boost. Sub-Saharan Africa, however, is still “of great concern.”
Taking into account the varied costs of living around the world, the World Bank uses income of $1.90 a day as its international poverty line, up from $1.25. Here’s a quick visual explainer:
The new #extremepoverty line is set to $1.90 per day, but what exactly is a poverty line? pic.twitter.com/58w6eKgyuw
— World Bank (@WorldBank) October 5, 2015 The latest figures put the World Bank on track to meet its ultimate goal of eradicating poverty by 2030, though it acknowledges there’s still much to be done.
